CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: 35 On the other hand , Li and co-workers employed the difluoro-substituted thiopheneconjugated side chain to construct bi(alkyl-difluorothienyl)benzodithiophene-fluorobenzotriazole copolymer J91 , which was shown to exhibit superior cell performance than that of the Article nonfluorinated control polymer. The PSC based on J91 / m-ITIC as an active layer with thermal annealing gave a high PCE of 11.63% with a high V oc of 0.98 V and a J sc of 18.03 mA cm^-2 . 36 The improved cell performance was attributed to the suppression of carrier recombination imposed by the difluorosubstituted side chain. In addition to influencing molecular and functional properties of donor polymers , the structural modification could lead to severe aggregation , which could hamper solution processability of a polymer. On the other hand , aggregation could be desirable and provide a useful tool to control the bulkheterojunction ( BHJ ) film morphology and then the photovoltaic performance of a solar cell. Yan and co-workers employed the branched alkyl chains attached on the backbone of the difluorobenzothiadiazole-quaterthiophene ( PffBT4T ) copolymer to acquire desirable temperature - dependent aggregation behavior. By spin - casting the polymer solution at an elevated temperature , they could control the morphology and crystallinity of the polymer films. Taking advantage of this aggregation control approach , high - performance PSCs based on PffBT4T-2OD:PC71BM were fabricated affording a PCE of up to 10.8% . 9 Guo and co-workers used a number of fused thiophene spacers to tune the aggregation behavior of difluorobenzoxadiazole (ffBX)-based donor polymers among which PffBX-TT with thieno[3,2-b]thiophene as a spacer showed intermediate temperature - dependent aggregation strength allowing the control of blend film morphology during PSC fabrication. PSCs using PffBX-TT:PC71BM as an active layer gave a maximum PCE of 9.10% . 37 Previously , we developed a class of benzodithiophene - based donor polymers with fluoro-dialkylthienylbenzothiadiazole being an acceptor unit that showed interesting temperature - dependent aggregation behavior when equipped with linear alkyl side chains. PSCs based on these polymers : PC71BM blend layers showed good photovoltaic performance with a maximum PCE as high as 9.70% . 38 In this contribution , we reported a new series of donor polymer materials based on benzodithiophene ( BDT ) and difluorinated dialkylthienylbenzothiadiazole , PffBB-n ( n = 10 , 12 , 14 , or 16 ) , which exhibited strong aggregation behavior in both solution and thin films. In addition to the size of alkyl side chains attached on the backbone of the polymer , aggregation can be modulated by the solvent used and temperature applied on the film with which the absorption cut - off extended down to ∼ 780 nm in thin films , resulting in a narrow optical band gap of ∼ 1.6 eV. Such wide absorption is desirable and complementary to that of the commonly used PC71BM acceptor material in the visible light region , which can increase light harvesting in BHJ PSCs.

Let's think step by step.

1. difluoro-substituted thiopheneconjugated side chain
2. nonfluorinated control polymer
3. J91
4. m-ITIC
5. donor polymers
6. branched alkyl chains
7. difluorobenzothiadiazole-quaterthiophene (PffBT4T) copolymer
8. fused thiophene spacers
9. difluorobenzoxadiazole (ffBX)-based donor polymers
10. thieno[3,2-b]thiophene
11. benzodithiophene-based donor polymers
12. fluoro-dialkylthienylbenzothiadiazole
13. donor polymer materials based on benzodithiophene (BDT) and difluorinated dialkylthienylbenzothiadiazole, PffBB-n (n = 10, 12, 14, or 16)
14. alkyl side chains
15. solvent
16. thin films
17. PC71BM acceptor material

Note: Some of the entities listed above are classes of materials, while others are specific material names.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Material Name.

10. PC71BM acceptor material

Yan and co-workers employed the branched alkyl chains attached on the backbone of the difluorobenzothiadiazole-quaterthiophene ( PffBT4T ) copolymer to acquire desirable temperature - dependent aggregation behavior. PV.content:
Please identify the Values (number + unit) of material properties in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: 35 On the other hand , Li and co-workers employed the difluoro-substituted thiopheneconjugated side chain to construct bi(alkyl-difluorothienyl)benzodithiophene-fluorobenzotriazole copolymer J91 , which was shown to exhibit superior cell performance than that of the Article nonfluorinated control polymer. The PSC based on J91 / m-ITIC as an active layer with thermal annealing gave a high PCE of 11.63% with a high V oc of 0.98 V and a J sc of 18.03 mA cm^-2 . 36 The improved cell performance was attributed to the suppression of carrier recombination imposed by the difluorosubstituted side chain. In addition to influencing molecular and functional properties of donor polymers , the structural modification could lead to severe aggregation , which could hamper solution processability of a polymer. On the other hand , aggregation could be desirable and provide a useful tool to control the bulkheterojunction ( BHJ ) film morphology and then the photovoltaic performance of a solar cell. Yan and co-workers employed the branched alkyl chains attached on the backbone of the difluorobenzothiadiazole-quaterthiophene ( PffBT4T ) copolymer to acquire desirable temperature - dependent aggregation behavior. By spin - casting the polymer solution at an elevated temperature , they could control the morphology and crystallinity of the polymer films. Taking advantage of this aggregation control approach , high - performance PSCs based on PffBT4T-2OD:PC71BM were fabricated affording a PCE of up to 10.8% . 9 Guo and co-workers used a number of fused thiophene spacers to tune the aggregation behavior of difluorobenzoxadiazole (ffBX)-based donor polymers among which PffBX-TT with thieno[3,2-b]thiophene as a spacer showed intermediate temperature - dependent aggregation strength allowing the control of blend film morphology during PSC fabrication. PSCs using PffBX-TT:PC71BM as an active layer gave a maximum PCE of 9.10% . 37 Previously , we developed a class of benzodithiophene - based donor polymers with fluoro-dialkylthienylbenzothiadiazole being an acceptor unit that showed interesting temperature - dependent aggregation behavior when equipped with linear alkyl side chains. PSCs based on these polymers : PC71BM blend layers showed good photovoltaic performance with a maximum PCE as high as 9.70% . 38 In this contribution , we reported a new series of donor polymer materials based on benzodithiophene ( BDT ) and difluorinated dialkylthienylbenzothiadiazole , PffBB-n ( n = 10 , 12 , 14 , or 16 ) , which exhibited strong aggregation behavior in both solution and thin films. In addition to the size of alkyl side chains attached on the backbone of the polymer , aggregation can be modulated by the solvent used and temperature applied on the film with which the absorption cut - off extended down to ∼ 780 nm in thin films , resulting in a narrow optical band gap of ∼ 1.6 eV. Such wide absorption is desirable and complementary to that of the commonly used PC71BM acceptor material in the visible light region , which can increase light harvesting in BHJ PSCs.

Let's think step by step.

1. High PCE of 11.63%: PCE stands for Power Conversion Efficiency, which is a measure of the efficiency of a solar cell in converting sunlight into usable electrical power. The unit for PCE is percentage (%).
2. A high Voc of 0.98 V: Voc stands for Open-Circuit Voltage, which is the maximum voltage that can be produced by a solar cell. The unit for Voc is Volts (V).
3. A Jsc of 18.03 mA cm^-2: Jsc stands for Short-Circuit Current Density, which is the current produced by a solar cell when the voltage is zero. The unit for Jsc is milliamperes per square centimeter (mA cm^-2).
4. Aggregation control approach: This is not a material property with a unit, but rather a process used to control the morphology and crystallinity of polymer films.
5. A maximum PCE of 10.8%: PCE stands for Power Conversion Efficiency, which is a measure of the efficiency of a solar cell in converting sunlight into usable electrical power. The unit for PCE is percentage (%).
6. Intermediate temperature-dependent aggregation strength: This is not a material property with a unit, but rather a description of the tendency of a material to aggregate (form clusters) in response to temperature changes.
7. A maximum PCE as high as 9.70%: PCE stands for Power Conversion Efficiency, which is a measure of the efficiency of a solar cell in converting sunlight into usable electrical power. The unit for PCE is percentage (%).
8. Strong aggregation behavior in both solution and thin films: This is not a material property with a unit, but rather a description of the tendency of a material to aggregate (form clusters) in both solution and thin film states.
9. A narrow optical band gap of ~1.6 eV: The optical band gap is a measure of the energy required to excite an electron from the valence band to the conduction band in a material. The unit for the optical band gap is electron volts (eV).
10. Absorption cut-off extended down to ~780 nm in thin films: The absorption cut-off is the wavelength at which a material stops absorbing light. The unit for wavelength is nanometers (nm).

Therefore, the material properties with values and units in the given paragraph are:

* PCE of 11.63%
* Voc of 0.98 V
* Jsc of 18.03 mA cm^-2
* PCE of 10.8%
* Intermediate temperature-dependent aggregation strength
* PCE of 9.70%
* Optical band gap of ~1.6 eV
* Absorption cut-off of ~780 nm in thin films.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Value of Material Property.

* PCE of 11.63%
* Voc of 0.98 V
* Jsc of 18.03 mA cm^-2
* PCE of 10.8%
* Optical band gap of ~1.6 eV
* Absorption cut-off of ~780 nm in thin films.
